concept.title: Conditions in cross-references
concept.shortdesc: The standard DITA metadata attributes of audience, platform, product, and otherprops can be applied to xref elements to allow conditional processing of cross-references. Positioning cross-references at the end of a sentence makes it easier to exclude the cross-reference without affecting the sense of the sentence.

conbody.p: If you need to cross-reference different resources for different publication variants, use the audience attribute to define these conditions. For example, if the PDF version of the output links to a different resource than the Help version, you could include two adjacent xref elements, one with the audience attribute set to pdf_user, and the other set to help_user.

If you are using cross-references in conjunction with conditional processing, positioning an in-text cross-reference (xref) element at the end of a sentence makes it easier to exclude.

For example, if a cross-reference is to be included in the Web rendition of a DITA collection, but excluded from the PDF rendition, then audience attribute might be used to differentiate the PDF-only text.

section.title: Rationale

lq.reftitle: Paul Masalsky, Yahoo! DITA Users Group
lq.p: We have this situation for cross references, too. Some topics are included in PDFs but not in help systems. Other topics, included in both PDF and help, might cross reference topics that are excluded from the help systems.

To include those cross references for PDF, we use (or similar for the parent of , such as a

). To exclude them for help generation, we specify audience="help_user" in our ditaval files, which has the effect of excluding the cross references identified by audience="PDF_user".It bends the meaning of the "audience" attribute a bit, but we find it has worked pretty well.

lq.reftitle: Patrick Quinlan, Yahoo! DITA Users Group

section.lq: We've run into a similar, though reversed, issue where we have xrefs that are fine in the PDF, but we don't want them in the HTML. Our solution is to train authors to place that kind of xref at the beginning or end of a sentence. For example: The vDisk store can be accessed by the farm, as shown in <xref="figure reference"/>. The text ",as shown in <xref="figure reference"/>" is marked with a PDF condition. The result for PDF: The vDisk store can be accessed by the farm, as shown in Figure 5 on page 117. The result for HTML: The vDisk store can be accessed by the farm.
